content:
lass="word-wrap-span">BRITAIN’S lass="word-wrap-span">RELIGIOUS leaders, a relatively small and lass="word-wrap-span">embattled community in an ever more secular land, are wondering what to make of lass="word-wrap-span">Boris lass="word-wrap-span">Johnson. As with many areas of his lass="word-wrap-span">chaotic life, the new prime minister’s spiritual lass="word-wrap-span">antecedents, and his present lass="word-wrap-span">convictions, are a lass="word-wrap-span">bundle of contrasts and confusion.

In a nutshell, he has lass="word-wrap-span">Muslim, Jewish and lass="word-wrap-span">Christian ancestors. He was lass="word-wrap-span">christened a lass="word-wrap-span">Catholic by his mother. He was conlass="word-wrap-span">firmed in the lass="word-wrap-span">Anglican faith (thus lass="word-wrap-span">formally lapsing from lass="word-wrap-span">Catholicism) while attending Eton lass="word-wrap-span">College, lass="word-wrap-span">Britain’s poshest school. In 2015 he told an lass="word-wrap-span">interviewer it would be “pretentious” to call himself a “serious, practising lass="word-wrap-span">Christian”. lass="word-wrap-span">But as a guest on “lass="word-wrap-span">Desert lass="word-wrap-span">Island lass="word-wrap-span">Discs”, a lass="word-wrap-span">BBC radio programme in which celebrities imagine themselves as lass="word-wrap-span">castaways, he said he would “sing a few lass="word-wrap-span">hymns and march up and down” to keep his morale up. On the other hand, none of the music he chose to have played on the show was spiritual: it ranged from lass="word-wrap-span">Brahms to punk-rock.

lass="word-wrap-span">Seven lass="word-wrap-span">Christian lass="word-wrap-span">denominations, mostly non-lass="word-wrap-span">conformist, have already written to him warning that no-deal Brexit, an option he is lass="word-wrap-span">firmly keeping on the table, will lass="word-wrap-span">exacerbate poverty and food shortages. lass="word-wrap-span">Although not a signatory of that letter, lass="word-wrap-span">Archbishop lass="word-wrap-span">Justin lass="word-wrap-span">Welby, the head of lass="word-wrap-span">England’s lass="word-wrap-span">established church and a fellow Etonian, is known to share that worry.

lass="word-wrap-span">Catholics have observed that Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Johnson is the first person baptised into their faith who has been master of 10 lass="word-wrap-span">Downing lass="word-wrap-span">Street, the prime ministerial residence, and that his lass="word-wrap-span">godmother came from a lass="word-wrap-span">fervently lass="word-wrap-span">Papist family. lass="word-wrap-span">But the lass="word-wrap-span">Roman faith doesn’t seem to have left much mark on him, to judge by the prime minister’s professed lass="word-wrap-span">indifference to monogamy.

Jewish lass="word-wrap-span">commentators noted with lass="word-wrap-span">approval that as foreign secretary, Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Johnson visited the lass="word-wrap-span">Western lass="word-wrap-span">Wall in lass="word-wrap-span">Jerusalem, spoke lass="word-wrap-span">fondly of his Jewish roots, and praised Israel as the region’s only democracy. lass="word-wrap-span">But his immediate Jewish ancestors were not lass="word-wrap-span">devout. Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Johnson’s great-grandfather lass="word-wrap-span">Elias lass="word-wrap-span">Avery lass="word-wrap-span">Lowe, a Russian-lass="word-wrap-span">American palaeographer, never practised Judaism and seemed more interested in Latin texts, including lass="word-wrap-span">Christian ones, than in Hebrew ones. lass="word-wrap-span">Lowe’s mother was said to come from a rabbinical line lass="word-wrap-span">But the link is distant.

lass="word-wrap-span">Meanwhile a lass="word-wrap-span">Muslim businessman, lass="word-wrap-span">Mohammad Amin, responded to Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Johnson’s lass="word-wrap-span">elevation by resigning from the lass="word-wrap-span">Tory party in protest at the politician’s record of inflammalass="word-wrap-span">Tory references to lass="word-wrap-span">Islamic face-veils (such as “letter-boxes”). Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Johnson defends his stance by saying his own lass="word-wrap-span">Muslim great-grandfather, the lass="word-wrap-span">Ottoman politician lass="word-wrap-span">Ali Kemal, admired lass="word-wrap-span">England because it was a land of openness and tolerance: that is the spirit he now wants to preserve.

lass="word-wrap-span">Over and above these more or less tenuous connections to the Abrahamic faiths, there is another worldview which, in the view of Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Johnson’s lass="word-wrap-span">biographer Andrew Gimson, holds much stronger personal appeal for the new prime minister: the polytheism of ancient lass="word-wrap-span">Greece and lass="word-wrap-span">Rome, whose literature he studied at lass="word-wrap-span">Oxford lass="word-wrap-span">University.

In fact, Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Johnson has some sympathy with the view that lass="word-wrap-span">Christianity, with its lass="word-wrap-span">emphasis on guilt, meekness and self-lass="word-wrap-span">denial, sapped the strength of the lass="word-wrap-span">Roman lass="word-wrap-span">Empire. As Mr Gimson notes, “it is clear that [Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Johnson] is inspired by the lass="word-wrap-span">Romans, and even more by the Greeks, and repelled by the early lass="word-wrap-span">Christians.”

lass="word-wrap-span">The prime minister lass="word-wrap-span">apparently shares lass="word-wrap-span">The classical belief in omens and portents, along with a lass="word-wrap-span">Homeric sense that great lass="word-wrap-span">heroes should be free to act out lass="word-wrap-span">Their passions and break free from moral lass="word-wrap-span">constraints. lass="word-wrap-span">All that may sound like an utter lass="word-wrap-span">contradiction with lass="word-wrap-span">The conventional forms of lass="word-wrap-span">Christianity that marked Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Johnson’s upbringing and education.

lass="word-wrap-span">But that lass="word-wrap-span">contradiction is hardly unique to Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Johnson. It pervades lass="word-wrap-span">The entire cultural tradition in which he was raised. lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">educational lass="word-wrap-span">ethos of 19th-century lass="word-wrap-span">Britain, which is still palpable in some private schools and ancient universities, aimed to revere both lass="word-wrap-span">The classical tradition and lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Christian one in equal measure. It lass="word-wrap-span">Therefore played down lass="word-wrap-span">The many points of difference between lass="word-wrap-span">The two. lass="word-wrap-span">Only a few people have been rude and clear-sighted enough to point this out. Edward lass="word-wrap-span">Gibbon (1737-1794), lass="word-wrap-span">The anti-lass="word-wrap-span">Christian lass="word-wrap-span">chronicler of lass="word-wrap-span">Rome’s decline, was one; Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Johnson may be anolass="word-wrap-span">Ther.

lass="word-wrap-span">Yet that will not stop him belting out childhood lass="word-wrap-span">hymns if he finds himself on a desert island. lass="word-wrap-span">Given Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Johnson’s background, he will be perfectly at ease with lass="word-wrap-span">ceremonial duties in which he and lass="word-wrap-span">Archbishop lass="word-wrap-span">Welby must rub shoulders as fellow members of the lass="word-wrap-span">establishment. lass="word-wrap-span">Indeed, under lass="word-wrap-span">England’s quirky constitution he will have at least a lass="word-wrap-span">formal role in choosing the lass="word-wrap-span">Archbishop’s successor. Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Johnson may not be much of a lass="word-wrap-span">Christian, but he is comfortable enough with lass="word-wrap-span">Anglicanism—an easy-going tradition which, since the era of Elizabeth I (1558-1603), has never lass="word-wrap-span">aspired “to make windows into men’s souls”.
